intro: Calymenia, commonly known as the "ghost flower," is a genus of flowering plants belonging to the family Calymariaceae. These plants are characterized by their unique, often delicate inflorescences that resemble ghostly shapes, hence their common name. Calymenia species are typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, thriving in humid, shaded environments. Their flowers are usually small and showy, with intricate structures that aid in pollination by specific insect species. The genus is of interest to botanists due to its evolutionary significance and ecological role in diverse habitats.
